discussion.content:
can someone explain why "api_base_uri" is used?
i cant see this as a defined variable

comments.content:
It's the only thing left that makes sense for a variable name, which will then be assigned to the "host" var.
Since we don't know the structure of the args.api_params (api_file), we can only guess.

kwargs - already used
args - makes no sense since its content is being used with api_params / api_file
api_file - already used
api_key - there is already an "api_key_id" being used two lines below
api_base_uri - can be interpreted as a host
result - makes no sense semantically
api_result - already used

DRAG DROP
-

Drag and drop the functions from the left onto the networking devices on the right.

//IMG//

comments.content: ff02::1 Switches will foward this by default, but for IPV4 must be enabled, I believe for IPV6 its disabled by routers to do multicasting

discussion.content:
i think its

loadbalancer - distibutes unicast traffic over devices
switch - distributes multicast traffic over devices
firewall - uses traffic inspection to make forwarding decisions
router - forwards by default

Switch forwards traffic by default, using MAC addresses to direct frames within a local area network (LAN).
Load balancer distributes unicast traffic, typically balancing the load among multiple servers for redundancy or performance.
Firewall inspects packets and makes decisions on whether to allow or block them based on security policies.
Router handles multicast traffic, which is sent to multiple destinations but not broadcast to all nodes.
loadbalancer- distributes unicast traffic over devices switch-forwards by default firewall- uses traffic inspection to make forwarding decisions router- distributes multicast traffic over devices

loadbalancer- distributes unicast traffic over devices
switch-forwards by default
firewall- uses traffic inspection to make forwarding decisions
router- distributes multicast traffic over devices

questions.question_text: Which technology is responsible for resolving a host name to an IP address?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Option C. - Since servers are in different networks, they need a router to communicate. The router does not send the packets to the firewall because the next hop is on the same interface that connects down to the servers.

tricky. It is missing the word "between", so server 1 and 2 traffic would go up to the firewall, before going out to the internet. Still it makes more sense Device C (router) for communication between the servers.

Selected Answer: D
if the communication is between server 1 and server 2, why would the router forward to the firewall?

Selected Answer: C
I would say C but whatever Cisco

Selected Answer: C
Why not Device D? router can make the two vlans talk to each other as well without the need of taking this to firewall.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Up to which device does the communication server 1 and server 2 go?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Must be next_url = response_json['metadata']['links']['next']

A is the correct answer

https://github.com/CiscoSecurity/amp-03-pagination/blob/master/01_paginate.py

while 'next' in response_json['metadata']['links']:
 next_url = response_json['metadata']['links']['next']
 response = session.get(next_url)
 response_json = response.json()
 for computer in response_json['data']:
 print(computer['connector_guid'], computer['hostname'])
